Maladies Treated: High fever, delirium, and convulsions associated with warm febrile diseases
Loss of consciousness and delirium accompanied by spitting blood, nose bleeding, or bruises
Medical Function: Lowers the penetrating quality of capillaries
Dosage: Oral intake: grind with water or powder form, 0.9 g to 1.8 g; in decoction form: 1.5 g to 6 g. External application: grind with water and apply.
Samples of Formulae: Xi jiao di huang tang (犀角地黃湯). For high fever, delirium, and convulsions associated with warm febrile diseases: combine xi jiao with ling yang jiao (antelope horn). For treatment of loss of consciousness and delirium with spitting blood, nose bleeding, or bruises: combine xi jiao with dan pi (moutan bark), da qing ye (indigo leaf), zi cao (lithospermum). Or combine xi jiao with huang lian (coptis), xuan shen (figwort root). Add water and make into decoction and take orally. For infantile convulsion: raw xi jiao added to water and ground into paste form or powdered form mixed with drinking water, taken orally.
Contraindications: Not to be used during pregnancy or in sickness without high fever. Do not use in cases of spleen deficiency.
Research: Buffalo horn can be used as a substitute for xi jiao in clinical practice.

Name: shan zha
Biological: C. pinnatifida Bge.ver. major N.E.Br. (山裏紅)

Geography: grown in northeastern and northern parts of China and Shaanxi, Henan, Shandong, Jiangsu provinces
Mainly produced in Hebei, Henan, Shandong, Liaoning provinces of China
Maladies Treated: acute pain in chest and abdomen area

small children malnutrition due to erratic feeding, Syndrome: yellowish face color, bulging abdomen, lack of appetite, or vomiting after meal, or diarrhea with undigested food. Use shan zha with bian dou, mu xiang, rou dou kou to strengthen digestion and rid of the syndrome.
early stage dysentery, passing mucus and blood in stool, abdominal pain, tenesmus, no chills or fever, use alone or cook with black tea

postpartum stagnated blood, incomplete discharge of lochia, lower abdominal pain, combine with yi mu cao (motherwort), dang gui (angelica root), chuan xiong (ligusticum root) for moving blood and dispersing stagnation, combine with pu huang (bulrush pollen), qian cao (madder root) to move blood and stop bleeding
amenorrhea with abdominal pain, commonly combined with dang gui wei (tail of angelica), hong hua (safflower), xiang fu (cyperus) for moving blood and qi stagnation
modernly beneficial for treatment of high lipids, arteriosclerosis, and hypertension
tapeworm infection, folk usage: eat large amounts of fresh shan zha as snack, next morning take decoction of bing lang (areca nut) to expel whole tapeworm
Medical Function: total flavonoids can improve coronary circulation
anti lack of oxygen of cardiac muscles in experimental setting (animal experiment)
shan zha solution significantly lowers blood cholesterol and triglyceride levels
lipase of shan zha promotes resolution of fat, aids digestion
crataegolic acid in shan zha promotes protein-decomposing enzyme activity aiding digestion
shan zha decoction and alcohol extract have antimicrobial activity against Shigella flexneri, Shigella sonnei, Proteobacteria, and Escherichia coli [1]
being used in high lipids, arteriosclerosis, and hypertension
Dosage: Generally 10 to 15 g. Large dosage can be 30 to 120g.
Samples of Formulae:
Indigestion (also called dyspepsia). Symptoms: fullness, bloating, burping, nausea, lack of appetite, or difficulty defecating, foul-smelling stool. Make decoction with shan zha or make it into powder. Combining shan zha with shen qu (medicated leaven), mai ya (barley sprout), zhi ke (bitter orange), bai zhu (atractylodes) enhances digestion. 
 For small children's malnutrition due to erratic feeding, symptoms include yellowish facial color, bulging abdomen, lack of appetite, vomiting after meals, or diarrhea with undigested food, combine shan zha with bian dou (hyacinth bean), mu xiang (aucklandia root), rou dou kou (nutmeg) to strengthen digestion and treat syndrome. 
 For early dysentery syndrome with mucus and blood in stool, abdominal pain, urgency without chills or fever, use shan zha alone or with black tea. 
 Postpartum stagnation of blood, incomplete lochia discharge, lower abdominal pain treated by combining shan zha with yi mu cao (motherwort), dang gui (angelica root), chuan xiong (ligusticum root) to activate blood circulation, or with pu huang (bulrush pollen), qian cao (madder root) to stop bleeding. 
 For amenorrhea and abdominal pain, shan zha is commonly combined with dang gui wei (angelica tail), hong hua (safflower), xiang fu (cyperus). 
 In modern clinical use for high blood lipids, arteriosclerosis, and hypertension. 
 Folk usage: large quantity of fresh shan zha taken as snack, then next morning taking a decoction of bing lang (areca nut) can expel entire tapeworm; dosage for decoction usually 9-12g, single decoction up to 30g, powdered form 3-6g.
Contraindications: Do not use in case of pixu (spleen deficient) without indigestion. Use with caution in cases of excess stomach acid, peptic ulcers, and pregnancies (to avoid premature delivery).
Research: Shan zha solution significantly lowers blood cholesterol and triglyceride levels. Decoction and alcohol extract have antibacterial activity against Shigella flexneri, Shigella sonnei, Proteobacteria, and Escherichia coli. [1]
References: [1] 山楂煎劑和乙醇提取物有抗菌作用對：福氏 (Shigella flexneri)痢疾桿菌，宋內氏(Shigella sonnei)痢疾桿菌, 變形杆菌 (Proteobacteria), 大腸桿菌 (Escherichia coli) 均有抗菌作用。

Name: ban lan gen
da qing ye
Biological: Strobilanthes cusia (Nees) O. Ktze (nan ban lan 南板蓝根, 青黛 馬蓝)
Isatis indigotica Fort. (bei ban lan 北板藍)
Strobilanthes divaricatus (Nees) T. Anders.(shu hua ma lan 疏花馬藍)

Maladies Treated: rose-colored skin rash caused by diseases such as measles, syphilis, scarlet fever and toxic heat
skin eruption due to wind-heat and other external skin diseases
ulcer of the mouth in children
Medical Function: inhibition of platelet aggregation: ban lan gen significantly inhibited platelet aggregation induced by adenosine diphosphate on domesticated rabbits. Uridine, hypoxanthine, pyrimidine, salicylic acid extracted from ban lan gen also exhibited inhibitory activity on adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-induced platelet aggregation in rabbits at concentration of 0.21mg/kg. Inhibition rates were 18.2%, 24.2%, 10.8% and 20% respectively.

effect on cardiovascular system: Increase in perfusion of isolated rabbit ear blood vessels and lower limbs of lab rats, improved rabbit mesenteric microcirculation, reduced the blood pressure in anesthetized rabbits, reduced capillary permeability, and lowered myocardial oxygen consumption in mice.

detoxification action: It has been reported that pre-administration with ban lan gen, huanglian powder (coptis), and li lu (veratrum) for dogs (dosage each 2.0g/kg) can detoxify li lu poisoning and decrease mortality. However, if administered after li lu poisoning, it is ineffective. Single use of either ban lan gen powder or huanglian powder was also found less effective.
Samples of Formulae: Acute hepatitis with jaundice: ban lan gen 30 g, zhi zi root 45 g. Make into concoction. Total patients treated: 53. All patients healed. Duration of therapy: 10 to 50 days [7].
Contraindications: Not to use in absence of fire toxin or in weak patients. Reports indicated prolonged usage may cause internal bleeding and injury to blood-producing function. Injections have reportedly caused allergic reactions and blood in urine. Allergic reactions include dizziness, rash, purple lips and face, numbness in limbs, serious cases may result in shock. Large dosages or long-term usage can be toxic to kidneys.

Geography: Widely distributed. Produced in Henan, Jiangsu, Zhejiang, Sichuan provinces.
Maladies Treated: vaginal discharge (red, white, or yellow, chronic, causing emaciation and weakness, lack of appetite, potentially leading to infertility)
hemorrhoids accompanied by bleeding or pus
Medical Function: Used for treating chronic diarrhea, bleeding outside menstruation periods, vaginal discharge, hemorrhoids and hemorrhoids accompanied by bleeding or pus.
Dosage: Taking orally, in decoction: 9 to 15 g. or mix into pill or powder. External application: use appropriate amount in powder form or make into paste.
Samples of Formulae: For chronic vaginal discharge (red, white, or yellow), emaciation and weakness, lack of appetite which may lead to infertility: Prescription: mo li (oyster shell), fu long gan (terra flava usta), chi shi zhi (halloysite), bai long gu (white fossil bone), gui xin (cinnamon bark), wu ze gu (cuttlefish bone), yu yu liang (limonite), each ingredient in equal amount. Make into powder. Take 2 grams each time with rice wine on an empty stomach twice a day. If discharge is predominantly white, increase the amount of mo li (oyster shell), long gu (fossil bone), wu ze gu (cuttlefish bone). If predominantly red, increase the amount of chi shi zhi (halloysite), yu yu liang (limonite). If predominantly yellow, increase amount of fu long gan (terra flava usta), gui xin (cinnamon bark). Adjust formula according to syndrome. (source: Qian Jin Fang 《千金方》)
Contraindications: Use care in case of pregnancy.
Chemical Ingredients: The mineral yu yu liang contains sand and gravels, organic matter. It contains approximately 20 to 78% 2Fe2O3.3H2O.
Often contains large amounts of phosphate.
Those sold in the Qingdao city marketplace mainly contain Fe2O3 and also contain Al, Mg, K, Na, PO4.
